entry.title: Jewish Welfare Board Publications
entry.content:
Some of the most popular paraphernalia from Jewish soldiers serving in WW I and WW II (and the Korean war?) are books that were printed by the JWB (Jewish Welfare Board) and distributed to Jewish military personnel.  Siddurim, Machzorim, Tanachs, Haggadahs, Megillas and many other books/pamphlets/Jewish guides were printed by the thousands and are fairly easy to pick up today. If you're lucky, you can find one with a name & rank or some note written on the inside cover.

Here are some of the basics:

This is interesting - they used Tefillah K'tzarah for Shemonah Esrei........

A couple of cute postcards - would be really cool to have one that actually has a hand written message.... Apparently these were given to the soldiers as they returned to America; they'd send them to their families letting them know they were back on American soil and were heading home. Interesting details about the different types of postcards here.

Haggadah.......

A few somewhat less common pamphlets....
entry.summary: Some of the most popular paraphernalia from Jewish soldiers serving in WW I and WW II (and the Korean war?) are books that were printed by the JWB (Jewish Welfare Board) and distributed to Jewish military personnel. Siddurim, Machzorim, Tanachs, Haggadahs, Megillas and many other books/pamphlets/Jewish guides were printed by the thousands and are fairly easy to pick up today. If you're lucky, you can find one with a name & rank or some note written on the inside cover.

entry.title: Jewish German Almanac 1935 & 36 - Almanach des Schocken Verlags

link.title: Jewish German Almanac 1935 & 36 - Almanach des Schocken Verlags

entry.content:
This wasn't an extremely interesting find, but still cool. It's a pair of Jewish almanacs in German from 1935 and 1936. There seems to be a range of essays on different aspects and topics of Judaism and Zionism. One page that was particularly interesting was the list of global Jewish occupancy in the 1936 pamphlet (last image below). The almanacs were published by Schocken Verlag - a publishing company founded and owned by Salman (Zalman) Schocken. Salman eventually moved to Palestine and purchased the Ha'aretz newspaper. His descendants still have a 60% stake in the paper. You can read more about him on  wikipedia.

1935 almanac:

and 1936:
entry.summary: This wasn't an extremely interesting find, but still cool. It's a pair of Jewish almanacs in German from 1935 and 1936. There seems to be a range of essays on different aspects and topics of Judaism and Zionism. One page that was particularly interesting was the list of global Jewish occupancy in the 1936 pamphlet (last image below). The almanacs were published by Schocken Verlag - a publishing company founded and owned by Salman (Zalman) Schocken. Salman eventually moved to Palestine and purchased the Ha'aretz newspaper. His descendants still have a 60% stake in the paper. You can read more about him on wikipedia.

entry.title: Rabbi Moshe Sherer works to free jewish hostages of 1970 hijacking

link.title: Rabbi Moshe Sherer works to free jewish hostages of 1970 hijacking

entry.content:
These notes by Rabbi Moshe Sherer are from the commemorative album put out by Agudath Israel of America in 1999 - Rabbi Moshe Sherer, his life and his legacy. They detail Rabbi Sherer's efforts to get the last Jewish hostages of the 1970 TWA hijacking ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawson%27s_Field_hijackings) home in time for Rosh Hashana.

Although this is not a particularly old book, it is a commemorative album which seems somewhat hard to come by. In addition, I found the hour by hour narrative super fascinating.
entry.summary: These notes by Rabbi Moshe Sherer are from the commemorative album put out by Agudath Israel of America in 1999 - Rabbi Moshe Sherer, his life and his legacy. They detail Rabbi Sherer's efforts to get the last Jewish hostages of the 1970 TWA hijacking ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dawson%27s_Field_hijackings) home in time for Rosh Hashana. Although this is not a particularly old book, it is a commemorative album which seems somewhat hard to come by. In addition, I found the hour by hour narrative super fascinating.

entry.title: Sefarim printed right after WW II

link.title: Sefarim printed right after WW II

entry.content:
I'd like to continue last post's focus on material from post WW II. The following four sefarim are not from the DP camps but rather from Shanghai and from Mir in NY right after the war. Hopefully I'll do some future posts on WW II subject matter, with some sefarim printed by the American army for their soldiers, some Yidish and Hebrew books about the concentration camps written right after the war, and some general sefarim printed in the DP camps.

Ramban

Number one is a soft cover Ramban that says printed by Mir. The seller insisted it was printed in Shanghai, although I can't find any reference to that in the sefer itself. Lesson learned - be more vigilant and only buy something you can verify, at least to some minimal extent.

Shita Mekubetzes

Next is a shita mekubetzes on Nedarim printed by Yeshivas Mir in NY in 1947. Rabbi Avroham Kalmonowitz writes a very nice introduction about the importance of torah and how when the yeshiva was in Shanghai during the war and had extremely little to live on, they spent whatever they could to print sefarim.  The same when they came to NY; printing sefarim was one of the first things they did - even before they had a building for the yeshiva.

Maayana Shel Torah

Below is "Torah Kval" (Mayana shel Torah) in Yiddish, (two volumes; Bereishis, Shemos & Vayikra in one and the last two in the second volume) printed by Agudath Yisroel in Shanghai 1945. A couple of notes. 1. It has a clear name - seems it belonged to a Yechiel Efraim Halevi Shainwack.  2. This printing was dedicated to the author of the sefer who was killed by the Nazis in the Warsaw ghetto in 1943. 3. In the back of the first volume there is a gift note from a friend who signs off "Your brother in pain" 1946. It's hard to make out the complete name of the gifter.

Gemarah

Last is a Gemara Bechoros printed in Shanghai in about 1942. What is interesting is that it has a hand written name - Avroham Arbuz with a date, 8 Cheshvon 5703 (October 19, 1942). It then has a stamp that this sefer was from the property of the Bachur Avroham Yitzchak Yisroel Ben Tzvi Arbuz, a talmid of Mir who was niftar on 13 Shevat 5706 (January 15, 1946) in Shanghai. Sad. Couldn't find much online about this Arbuz, other than his name on a list of Mir talmidim (page 4 - number 97) and that apparently there are a plenty more sefarim with his name out there, as many people online also mention having sefarim with his name.
entry.summary: I'd like to continue last post's focus on material from post WW II. The following four sefarim are not from the DP camps but rather from Shanghai and from Mir in NY right after the war. Hopefully I'll do some future posts on WW II subject matter, with some sefarim printed by the American army for their soldiers, some Yidish and Hebrew books about the concentration camps written right after the war, and some general sefarim printed in the DP camps. Ramban

entry.title: DP Camp newspaper - Netzach Yisroel
entry.content: Below are some pages from a Yiddish magazine printed in the DP camps in 1948. It provides a very clear and unique insight to their day to day life - similar to picking up a newspaper today and flipping through it; you walk away with a straightforward snapshot of that day, not someone writing 50 years later trying to reconstruct a bygone era. Since it was a magazine though, the paper quality is terrible and it is really c rumbling apart. When I bought this one there was an identical copy also available - don't know what I was thinking but I just took the nicer of the two and left the second one there. Live and learn.... The last page is an index of the articles in this issue. Overall it is very heartening to see the strength and courage they displayed so few years after the war...

Since it was a magazine though, the paper quality is terrible and it is really c rumbling apart. When I bought this one there was an identical copy also available - don't know what I was thinking but I just took the nicer of the two and left the second one there. Live and learn.... The last page is an index of the articles in this issue. Overall it is very heartening to see the strength and courage they displayed so few years after the war...
